Configure Images in Content (ℹ️)

The Content App uses standard Image definitions like Content and Lightbox. Since these are standard 2sxc assets, they are not listed here but come from system settings. 

If you need to use a custom version you can override this in the settings of this App, of this Site or globally across all sites. See Settings in Docs.

You can also modify the Razor files to use any value you prefer, but we recommend to use the Settings-concept.

If you need to use a custom version you can override this in the settings of this App, of this Site or globally across all sites. See Settings in Docs.

You can also modify the Razor files to use any value you prefer, but we recommend to use the Settings-concept.

This site was originally a kind of Intranet for Accuraty. After years of community involvement (Discord, Slack, Stackoverflow, etc. across Tailwind, Bootstrap, WordPress, DNN, Astro, Svelte, and others), we often wanted to shared or link-to our problem+solution oriented write-ups (H2R2S). So we rebuilt ACCU4 to be public. Yes we found a few things that seemed like they were really private or internal and they got moved to appropriate places.

  1. H2R2S stands for Help, How-to, Reminders, Recipes, and Setups. This site is an example of using the 2sxc Content App as a knowledge base and wiki.
  2. AccuTheme-Tw4, our in-house tool for custom DNN theming using Tailwind CSS v4+ is now open source and we are working towards making it attractive for others to consider using it as their DNN v10+ starting point for custom themes!
  3. AccuTrack is internal and has moved to [private].
  4. AccuThings - current useful things or ideas for future useful things
Main Purposes and Goals this ACCU4 Site

DNN v10.00.00 released Apr 9, 2025.

GitHub Branch is now the default, develop.

You can quickly get the latest version DNN v10 running on your local machine using nvQuickSITE.
DNN v10.0.x Reference

1. Go to GitHub, Dnn.Platform
  2. Switch to Branch: release/10.0.0
  3. In the Commits row, click the little green checkbox
  4. In the popup, click the Details (blue) link
  5. At the bottom of the main area, click View more details on Azure Pipelines
  6. In the Summary, under Related, click on "1 published"
  7. Hover on "Artifacts1", in the dropdown menu to the right, click "Download artifacts"
  8. Go to your (local File Explorer) Downloads folder
  9. Unzip "Artifacts1.zip" to a new folder
  10. In the Artifacts1.zip/Actifacts1 folder, you should now see the typical DNN Install, Upgrade, etc. zip files

To quickly get a local version up and running use nvQuickSite (Settings: Enable Local Package Install).

Search helpers: Artifacts, Artifacts1

Whether basic or advanced, there is nothing like an example for learning how to do something.
DNN Themes: Misc Tips, Tricks, and Reminders

For a cool 2024 take on a performance optimized DnnJsInclude, please see Dnn-Elements in a 2sxc View. It shows loading ESM with type="module".

We want to use the Bootstrap 5.3+ docs, Getting Started with Bootstrap and get the complete Bootstrap CSS and JavaScript bundle on the page. When you check out the docs, notice the CSS and JS CDN includes have some pretty specific details in their attributes.

Here is how this would look translated to a DnnJsInclude in a DNN Theme:

<dnn:DnnCssInclude 
  FilePath="//cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/bootstrap@5/dist/css/bootstrap.min.css" 
  Priority="7" 
  ForceProvider="DnnPageHeaderProvider" 
  HtmlAttributesAsString="async defer crossorigin:anonymous,rel:stylesheet" 
  runat="server" 
/>
<dnn:DnnJsInclude 
  FilePath="//cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/bootstrap@5/dist/js/bootstrap.bundle.min.js" 
  ForceProvider="DnnFormBottomProvider" 
  HtmlAttributesAsString="async defer crossorigin:anonymous" 
  runat="server" 
/>

The code above is from the ACCURATY.COM site and you can go there, view page source, and search for Bootstrap to see the actual output.

Things to notice:
  • The filepath starts with "//", this tells the browser to request the same http or https as the page is already using.
  • Priority 7 keeps the CSS at the right level for a theme resource.
  • For the JS, we use DnnFormBottomProvider and no priority because we don't really need the browser to load this early.
  • The DNN Docs for loading Client Resources are here.
Things Accuraty changed:
  • Since we want to stay up to date while avoiding breaking changes, we are only specifying the major version (@5) instead of @5.3.5. This takes advantage of a jsdelivr feature so we always get the latest v5.x.x, but will never get v6+.
  • Note that this means we cannot use intergrity. If you add an integrity check for v5.3.5, when v5.3.6 releases, your integrity check would fail and the asset would not load.
  • We introduced a hack. For the HtmlAttributeAsString values, instead of "async:async,defer:defer,crossorigin..." like you see in most other examples, we discovered that if you pass in "async defer crossorigin", you get cleaner output (just async instead of async="async"). This is because the parser does not care about spaces and just thinks the whole first value pair's name is "async defer crossorigin".
Advanced JS and CSS - includes/preheader.ascx

Until now, trying to style an article, document, or blog post with Tailwind has been a tedious task that required a keen eye for typography and a lot of complex custom CSS.

By default, Tailwind removes all of the default browser styling from paragraphs, headings, lists and more. This ends up being really useful for building application UIs because you spend less time undoing user-agent styles, but when you really are just trying to style some content that came from a rich-text editor in a CMS or a markdown file, it can be surprising and unintuitive.

We get lots of complaints about it actually, with people regularly asking us things like:

Why is Tailwind removing the default styles on my h1 elements? How do I disable this? What do you mean I lose all the other base styles too?

We hear you, but we're not convinced that simply disabling our base styles is what you really want. You don't want to have to remove annoying margins every time you use a p element in a piece of your dashboard UI. And I doubt you really want your blog posts to use the user-agent styles either — you want them to look awesome, not awful.

The @tailwindcss/typography plugin is our attempt to give you what you actually want, without any of the downsides of doing something stupid like disabling our base styles.

It adds a new prose class that you can slap on any block of vanilla HTML content and turn it into a beautiful, well-formatted document:

<article class="prose">
  <h1>Garlic bread with cheese: What the science tells us</h1>
  <p>
    For years parents have espoused the health benefits of eating garlic bread with cheese to their
    children, with the food earning such an iconic status in our culture that kids will often dress
    up as warm, cheesy loaf for Halloween.
  </p>
  <p>
    But a recent study shows that the celebrated appetizer may be linked to a series of rabies cases
    springing up around the country.
  </p>
  <!-- ... -->
</article>

For more information about how to use the plugin and the features it includes, read the documentation.

What to expect from here on out

What follows from here is just a bunch of absolute nonsense I've written to dogfood the plugin itself. It includes every sensible typographic element I could think of, like bold text, unordered lists, ordered lists, code blocks, block quotes, and even italics.

It's important to cover all of these use cases for a few reasons:

  1. We want everything to look good out of the box.
  2. Really just the first reason, that's the whole point of the plugin.
  3. Here's a third pretend reason though a list with three items looks more realistic than a list with two items.

Now we're going to try out another header style.

Typography should be easy

So that's a header for you — with any luck if we've done our job correctly that will look pretty reasonable.

Something a wise person once told me about typography is:

Typography is pretty important if you don't want your stuff to look like trash. Make it good then it won't be bad.

It's probably important that images look okay here by default as well:

Now I'm going to show you an example of an unordered list to make sure that looks good, too:

  • So here is the first item in this list.
  • In this example we're keeping the items short.
  • Later, we'll use longer, more complex list items.

And that's the end of this section.

What if we stack headings?

We should make sure that looks good, too.

Sometimes you have headings directly underneath each other. In those cases you often have to undo the top margin on the second heading because it usually looks better for the headings to be closer together than a paragraph followed by a heading should be.

When a heading comes after a paragraph …

When a heading comes after a paragraph, we need a bit more space, like I already mentioned above. Now let's see what a more complex list would look like.

  • I often do this thing where list items have headings.

    For some reason I think this looks cool which is unfortunate because it's pretty annoying to get the styles right.

    I often have two or three paragraphs in these list items, too, so the hard part is getting the spacing between the paragraphs, list item heading, and separate list items to all make sense. Pretty tough honestly, you could make a strong argument that you just shouldn't write this way.

  • Since this is a list, I need at least two items.

    I explained what I'm doing already in the previous list item, but a list wouldn't be a list if it only had one item, and we really want this to look realistic. That's why I've added this second list item so I actually have something to look at when writing the styles.

  • It's not a bad idea to add a third item either.

    I think it probably would've been fine to just use two items but three is definitely not worse, and since I seem to be having no trouble making up arbitrary things to type, I might as well include it.

After this sort of list I usually have a closing statement or paragraph, because it kinda looks weird jumping right to a heading.

What about nested lists?

Nested lists basically always look bad which is why editors like Medium don't even let you do it, but I guess since some of you goofballs are going to do it we have to carry the burden of at least making it work.

  1. Nested lists are rarely a good idea.
    • You might feel like you are being really "organized" or something but you are just creating a gross shape on the screen that is hard to read.
    • Nested navigation in UIs is a bad idea too, keep things as flat as possible.
    • Nesting tons of folders in your source code is also not helpful.
  2. Since we need to have more items, here's another one.
    • I'm not sure if we'll bother styling more than two levels deep.
    • Two is already too much, three is guaranteed to be a bad idea.
    • If you nest four levels deep you belong in prison.
  3. Two items isn't really a list, three is good though.
    • Again please don't nest lists if you want people to actually read your content.
    • Nobody wants to look at this.
    • I'm upset that we even have to bother styling this.

The most annoying thing about lists in Markdown is that <li> elements aren't given a child <p> tag unless there are multiple paragraphs in the list item. That means I have to worry about styling that annoying situation too.

  • For example, here's another nested list.

    But this time with a second paragraph.

    • These list items won't have <p> tags
    • Because they are only one line each

  • But in this second top-level list item, they will.

    This is especially annoying because of the spacing on this paragraph.

    • As you can see here, because I've added a second line, this list item now has a <p> tag.

      This is the second line I'm talking about by the way.

    • Finally here's another list item so it's more like a list.

  • A closing list item, but with no nested list, because why not?

And finally a sentence to close off this section.

There are other elements we need to style

I almost forgot to mention links, like this link to the Tailwind CSS website. We almost made them blue but that's so yesterday, so we went with dark gray, feels edgier.

We even included table styles, check it out:

Wrestler Origin Finisher
Bret "The Hitman" Hart Calgary, AB Sharpshooter
Stone Cold Steve Austin Austin, TX Stone Cold Stunner
Randy Savage Sarasota, FL Elbow Drop
Vader Boulder, CO Vader Bomb
Razor Ramon Chuluota, FL Razor's Edge
Typography, Prose, and Keeping the Pretty

DNN Roles and role names...

A necessary change to our (current and) future projects. DNN v10 will introduce two new default Roles thanks to the new Content Workflow and Approval features.

Here is how it affects us... 

Notice that these additions are plural. We had previous standardized (via AccuClone) on the role name, "Content Editor". So, moving forward, we are adding the 's'. This is already done on AccuClone.

As near as I can tell, there is no difference in intended use between our Content Editor and the new Content Editors roles. Content Managers is different because, in an approval role, they can make "draft content by Editors live."

In addition, to follow along, we are also renaming our Site Manager (which is different than Content Managers) to plural, "Site Managers" - again, already done in AccuClone.

Current projects:

  • if its not live yet, please get the existing two roles renamed to plural, then search and fix any code that would no longer work due to the rename
  • if it is already live (e.g. SVRRF), no changes, leave it alone. when we upgrade to DNN v10 (which won't be for a few months, we'll deal with it then

Steps to fix:

  • In the project in VS Code, search globally for "Content Manager" and "Site Manager." If found, add an "s" to both
  • in PB/Manage/Roles, if the Description field is empty, update them so the Role Name and Description fields are an exact match (below) and/or improve them to match the intended client/project usage. 

Questions? Comments? Ideas? Arguments against?
For Accuraty and AccuTheme Projects, A Change and Minor Cleanup

If you are in a position to improve these (making them more accurate for the client/project), please do. These are just the defaults; the starting point for an AccuTheme project on DNN v10+. 

Role Name Description
Content Editors Content editors are allowed to add and change content on this site. The exact functionality depends on the what the modules used on this site support.
Content Managers Content managers can decide what gets displayed on the website. They can change what content editors have contributed and decide if this gets published or not. The exact functionality depends on what the modules used on this site support.
Site Managers Site managers can do everything Content Editors and Managers can do and additionally add/move/edit pages.

Note that "Site Managers" is an AccuTheme and Accuraty project standard and not one of the default Roles in any version of DNN.
Correct Defaults for all Three Roles

Everyone thinks flexbox and grid have made it so easy to center things with CSS, but there are still a ton of situations where a simple `align-items: center` isn't quite the solution you need — even when you think it is.

A really common example of this is pricing cards, where you want to center a custom icon next to each feature in a list. It looks great at first, and then the marketing department makes the text a little longer

Responsive tables are the sort of nightmare that will make you and your team try to convince your boss that "no one ever uses our site on their phone anyways". Your CSS would be smaller if you just deleted all the breakpoints too, which leads to a faster loading site and surely will make your company more money!

I've built a lot of different responsive tables over the years, but honestly my favorite general purpose solution (especially for data-heavy stuff like dashboards) is to just make the table scrollable so mobile users can see all of the same content a desktop user would see.

This isn't easy though, especially if you want to get all of the details right.

Starting in the Summer of 2024 we noticed certain sites with significant increases in bot-stayle traffic and we had to start finding ways to address and prevent a serious CDoS (Crawler Detriment of Service) problem. When monitoring processes on the server, it was obvious that a site's app pool that would normally be in the 200-300 MB range was often ranging from 1.8 to 3.2 GB.

A.I. and Search Crawlers can conspire to turn some dynamic pages into millions of page requests. This costs money, damages reputations, slows everything down, and can inpire all kinds of confusing side effects from unnecessarily massive log files to customer complaints about slow page loads to your hosting provider incorrectly taking action thinking there was a DDoS attack.

Sidenote 20250515

Though not as useful as we'd hoped, Cloudflare's newer robots.txt related policies and tools provide another set of methods to be aware of. In May 2025 we were testing this on accuraty.com as you can see here. Still, more effort means better results, and there were significant long term gains.
CDoS? Ways to Address and Prevent A.I. and Search Crawler Attacks

Though our situation (and others) were made worse by alarmingly aggressive A.I. crawlers, this is not about A.I. being a problem. The real issue was pretty interesting and I believe the general term, though not yet coined, is either crawl-trap or spider-trap.

In general some dynamic website pages can cause search engine crawlers to get stuck in a loop, discovering an effectively infinite number of URLs, wasting resources crawling low-value or more specifically unique URLs with jumbles are indentical and repeated content. 

Recently the folks at 2sxc posted an excellent blog article, When AI Comes Crawling. This is a very interesting read, highly recommended for coders of 2sxc Views; the solutions and explanations of the features added to 2sxc URL Parameter Handling in v19+ are well worth your time!
A.I. Made Things Worse

We took on a project from a small local company. Part of their old website had a page that let visitors search for Providers. This data was imported manually and periodically from an old Microsoft Access managed database. 

At the left is the old form that you used to fill out, click search, wait a bit, and then get a really long page of results. 

You can try out our new (2022) version here: Find Care Providers.
Accuraty's Worse Case Scenario and the Many Solutions

Though we left (for now) their data management in Access, we happily took on modernizing the search with the addition of:

  • Paging
  • Print output formatting
  • Better wildcard based search
  • Sorting
  • Filtering
  • Lists; nice Card presentations
  • Detail pages
  • Optional profile images
Search, Sort, Filter, and a Card Based U.I.

With 3 checkboxes and 4 dropdowns selected, take a look at the URL (a.k.a. the problem):

https://www.cphp.com/Find-Care/Provider-Finder/carrier/cc/specialty/family-practice/affiliation/christie-clinic/gender/f/tier/1/pcp/1/telehealth/1/newp/1/anymh/0

Here is the real problem, swap those last two params and you have "a different page" with the same content as above:

https://www.cphp.com/Find-Care/Provider-Finder/carrier/cc/specialty/family-practice/affiliation/christie-clinic/gender/f/tier/1/pcp/1/telehealth/1/anymh/0/newp/1

Initially, we did nothing to sort the params, so both humans and crawlers could explore the filters in any order that made sense. If it hasn't clicked yet, this resulted in millions of unique URL combinations with over 90% of them displaying the same results. This mean the search and A.I. crawlers were hammering the site for new pages (unique URLs) all the time and often, overwhelmingly so.
Maintaining Filter State via URL Parameters...

1. robots.txt

We spent weeks re-learning and experimenting with robots.txt trying to either rate limit or block the bots. Even when you did it correctly (which was not always obvious), the A.I. crawlers simply ignored your settings. We thought this mattered, and spent a significant amount of time... but this turned out to be the least effective solution as well as most time consuming.

2. Cloudflare

Since summer 2024 their solutions to this have improved. They used to be just custom blocking you could setup. Now there are features you can turn on. This was sometimes effective, but often only for 3 to 5 days.

3. HTTP (IIS) Blocking Bad Robots

This helped but there were to many A.I. bots and name changes and within 3 weeks you were practically starting over crawling through your logs. Same as Cloudflare, sometimes good for a short-term fix.

4. URL Parameter Handling

We refactored our links so the parameters always sorted in the same order. This was helpful and long-term significant. But it only took the millions of unique URLs down to a few hundred thousand. :/

3,500 Provider Cards duplicating...

Since each filter presented new sets of paged Cards, the pages weren't technical duplicates, but there is no sense it re-showing each physician and nurse over and over again across different simlar pages of results.

5. Introduce a custom Canonical URL

This solution proved to be the best. Read on...
Some Good Solutions that Did Not Do Enough

I am sad to admit that the best fix did not make it on to my radar screen for almost 4 months. But once the thought triggered it was like a light saber springing to life. It took a few tries to rethink and understand the correct approach. Which meant asking the right question: 

How can I get only 1 copy of each record, for all my data to be indexed?

The answer was simple; for each Carrier, I needed every page of cards indexed once, with no filters on.

In other words, 
https://www.cphp.com/Find-Care/Provider-Finder/carrier/cc/pg/2
https://www.cphp.com/Find-Care/Provider-Finder/carrier/cc/pg/3
https://www.cphp.com/Find-Care/Provider-Finder/carrier/cc/pg/4 
...
https://www.cphp.com/Find-Care/Provider-Finder/carrier/cc/pg/311 

There were only two carriers, "cc" and "mc". 

So, setting the canonical URL for every possible page with only the URL params for carrier and pg (page number) meant that the search and A.I. indexers would know there were only about 500 unique pages. And even with the client upload-importing the new data 4 to 10 times per quarter, crawling is once again manageable and mostly unnoticeable.
The Tide is Turning: Canonical URLs Bring the Missing ROI

Note: since you are probably reading this after Feb 2025, if you can upgrade to the latest 2sxc v19+, you can simple use the new .Filter("carrier,pg") to replace much of the code below. However, you still have to handle the case where "pg" is not here and add it.

So above, go back and look at the two URLs above where I showed the 2 swapped params at the end. Both those pages now display this Canonical URL link in the page <head>:

<link rel="canonical" href="https://www.cphp.com/Find-Care/Provider-Finder/carrier/cc/pg/1" />

I would not call it pretty or elegant or performant. But it is also not a lot of code for a critical and final solution.


  // 20250222 START https://github.com/Accuraty/CPHP2022/issues/71
  // Set Page's Canonical URL Link to include ONLY carrier='' and pg=''
  // params we are ignoring: specialty, affiliation, gender, tier, pcp, telehealth, newp, anymh, print, debug
  // <head> ... <link rel="canonical" href="https://[domain.com]/[base]" />
  // using System.Collections.Specialized
  string templateLinkCanonical = "<link rel=\"canonical\" href=\"{0}\" />\r\n";
  NameValueCollection originalParameters = HttpUtility.ParseQueryString(CmsContext.Page.Parameters.ToString());

  NameValueCollection nameValues = new NameValueCollection();
  if (originalParameters["carrier"] != null)
  {
    nameValues.Add("carrier", originalParameters["carrier"]);
  }

  // eliminate page 1 duplicate (if no pg param, add /pg/1 anyhow)
  string pg = originalParameters["pg"] == null ? "1" : originalParameters["pg"];
  nameValues.Add("pg", pg);
  
  // Manually build the query string
  var newLink = string.Join("&", nameValues.AllKeys.Select(key => $"{HttpUtility.UrlEncode(key)}={HttpUtility.UrlEncode(nameValues[key])}"));
  newLink = Link.To(parameters: newLink);

  Kit.Page.AddToHead(string.Format(templateLinkCanonical, newLink));
  // 20250222 END ... /issues/71
The Code

All of these go through phases: 

  1. The idea
  2. One or more use-case implemented
  3. Basic standardizations for re-use; Content Type, App Settings, etc.
  4. Publish as an internal Accu[App]
  5. Use, Test, Revise (dog fooding)
  6. Publish for public use by others

Problem: figuring out Email hosting based on # of users, disk space used, and overages is PITA.

Solution: define rules (math) and automate using PowerShell and the available APIs. Run 9am last day of the month and again at 9am on the first day. Get (from DS2030/SmarterMail) # of licenses in use and storage usage for all users. Send email with math done to easily update monthly Memorized invoice.

For example, TMT/AHSE as of June 1, 2025: 30 licenses with 25 users below 500M, 5 users below 5G, and 2 users below 25G.

Code should look okay by default.

I think most people are going to use highlight.js or Prism or something if they want to style their code blocks but it wouldn't hurt to make them look okay out of the box, even with no syntax highlighting.

Here's what a default tailwind.config.js file looks like at the time of writing:

module.exports = {
  purge: [],
  theme: {
    extend: {},
  },
  variants: {},
  plugins: [],
}

Hopefully that looks good enough to you.

We also need to make sure inline code looks good, like if I wanted to talk about <span> elements or tell you the good news about @tailwindcss/typography.

Sometimes I even use code in headings

Even though it's probably a bad idea, and historically I've had a hard time making it look good. This "wrap the code blocks in backticks" trick works pretty well though really.

Another thing I've done in the past is put a code tag inside of a link, like if I wanted to tell you about the tailwindcss/docs repository. I don't love that there is an underline below the backticks but it is absolutely not worth the madness it would require to avoid it.

We haven't used an h4 yet

But now we have. Please don't use h5 or h6 in your content, Medium only supports two heading levels for a reason, you animals. I honestly considered using a before pseudo-element to scream at you if you use an h5 or h6.

We don't style them at all out of the box because h4 elements are already so small that they are the same size as the body copy. What are we supposed to do with an h5, make it smaller than the body copy? No thanks.

We still need to think about stacked headings though.

Let's make sure we don't screw that up with h4 elements, either.

Phew, with any luck we have styled the headings above this text and they look pretty good.

Let's add a closing paragraph here so things end with a decently sized block of text. I can't explain why I want things to end that way but I have to assume it's because I think things will look weird or unbalanced if there is a heading too close to the end of the document.

What I've written here is probably long enough, but adding this final sentence can't hurt.

We should not forget about the <samp> and <kbd>, the Sample output element.

Oh my, we just wrapped those in the <code> element and used them in a heading, does the styling, especially the size, look right?

In our OHS projects (usually AccuTheme-NnN based), we have .gitignore rules in place to prevent all the 2sxc/[appname]/AppCode/ files from getting included in our projects (when we bring them down local, from the server, to get IntelliSense). 

# 2sxc Content App Generated and app original cs files
**/Portals/**/2sxc/**/AppCode/**/*.cs
!**/Portals/**/2sxc/**/AppCode/**/*.Accu*.cs
!**/Portals/**/2sxc/**/AppCode/Accu/*.*

In English, the above 3 lines tell your VS Code to (for source control tracking):

  • ignore all files ending in .cs in any DNN portal in any 2sxc app
  • but then undo that for any files ending in .Accu.cs (or .Accuraty.cs)
  • or any files in a folder named Accu in the root of the AppCode folder.

So the point is, we want to a) ignore and not check in to our projects, all the pre-existing code from 2sxc apps. Conversely, if we add new code or change their existing code, we do want it checked in.
How to Ensure Our Custom Code Gets Checked In
The Basics for Content Editors and misc. reminders, best practices, and a few things (that are not obvious) that you should not do.
The Basics for Content Editors

1. Images - link to the existing page (filenames, etc)
  2. Images - common mistakes (don't format/crop/resize, don't add text, etc)
  3. Leave the style choices to the design
    1. Do not enter anything in all caps
    2. Never add emphasis (bold, italics, etc)
  4. Avoid too much text. You should use these two primary solutions instead:
    1. Disclosure and Accordion options
    2. Summarize and move the full (long) text to a linked (sub) page that is not in the navigation menu
  5. Limit lists to 3 to 5 items (bullets primarily, but this applies to anything, menus, etc), 
  6. When copy and pasting content, ensure you are pasting as plain text (Ctrl + Shift + V on Windows and Cmd + Shift + V on Mac).
WIP: Content Items to Develop...

On every project we customize the notification emails sent to the client. The original file is: EmailToOwner.cs

We do not edit that file and leave it as-is for two reasons:

  1. it is the original and if we are having problems with our custom code, its an excellent reference for comparison - because we know it works.
  2. if we modified that file as-is, the project (live website) would obviously work, but our customizations would not get checked in to GitHub with the rest of our work.

The full path to our example file is:
/Portals/**/2sxc/MobiusForms6/[live]/AppCode/MailTemplates/EmailToOwner.cs

So we simply copy+paste the existing file, renaming it as EmailToOwner.Accu.cs. This accomplishes the following:

  • our code/work will get checked in to the project (source control)
  • we know where we got the original code from (for comparison)
  • it makes our changes obvious to anyone working on the project in the future

In VS Code this means... as you can see in the screenclip, the greyed-out files are all the Mobius files that are installed as part of the app. The bright green means VS Code source control both recognizes it has changed (since your current branch started) and that it will be one of the files that it expects you to check in and merge (see Source Control, pending changes).
Common example for 2sxc's Mobius Forms

Quick Reminders on Images

File Names that Don't Break Things Examples:

  • director-operations-photo.jpg
  • Board-Series-May-2023-with-graphs-charts.pdf
  • logoCocaCola-w800.jpg

File names matter. Search engines use them to determine what is in the image, and good file names can help you, future you, and your coworkers work better, faster, and smarter! 

There are thousands of web browsing devices, and though there are standards, each one was developed with different rules about what characters a URL - or web address - can use. Some symbols have meaning; for example, question marks and ampersands have important roles when used in a URL. 

A question mark in a URL address will separate the URL from the URI. An ampersand will separate multiple parameters in the URI. An equals sign will separate the name and value in each URI parameter.

An underscore can hide your intended wording from Google search. Never use_underscores_ in filenames!

The point is, those symbols are part of the URL language. Since your file names become part of a URL, you cannot use those characters.

Rather than learn all the things you should NOT do in a file name, it is much easy and more productive to learn only the things you should do in naming your files. Keep it very simple: 

  • lowercase letters (upper case is okay sometimes)
  • numbers
  • a hyphen

That is it - except for using a dot (period) to separate your file name from it's extension (e.g. .jpg, .pdf). Nothing else at all.

Important: a space is a character (to computers). A space is not in the list above. Do not use it. Learn to use a hyphen instead of a space.
In-depth on Filenames for Images and all files

Once you know your file name is web-friendly, you can take it one step further by making sure your file names are friendly to search engines, too.

Let’s say that you’re trying to find a home for some kittens, and you want to post a listing online (example shown at right). If you take a picture, the file name might look like this:

Original file name: IMG_2542.jpg

That is is a valid file name... you could technically upload it as-is without causing any errors But if I want search engines to have an idea of what is in the picture, you will have to be a little more descriptive, like this:

Optimized file name: rescued-kittens-for-sale-bloomington-il.jpg

By separating the keywords with a hyphen (-), search engines know that I’m communicating separate words, (which is much better than labpuppiesforsalewinonamn).
Make Images and Filenames Part of Your Search Engine Strategy

A summary of the common Tailwind shorthand utilities including or related to inset, margin, padding, rounded, border, divide, space, gap, inline, block, start, and end. Consistency and reducing repetition.
Tailwind CSS Shorthand Utilities Summary

CSS: inset: <top> <right> <bottom> <left>;

Example: inset: 1rem;

is shorthand for

top: 1rem;
right: 1rem;
bottom: 1rem;
left: 1rem;

Tailwind's inset is a shorthand utility for positioning offsets (top, right, bottom, left). It makes absolute/fixed positioning much cleaner and more concise.

Tailwind usage:
<div class="relative">
  <!-- Absolutely positioned box in the top-left corner -->
  <div class="absolute inset-0 bg-blue-200"></div>  
  <!-- Absolutely positioned box with horizontal inset -->
  <div class="absolute inset-x-4 top-0 h-10 bg-red-300"></div>
</div>

A fantastic example of using it is in this 5 min video: Build UI's That Don't Suck.
What inset Does and How Tailwind Uses it

You can quickly get swept up in time-consuming frivilous lawsuits.

This is a real example from Sept 2025. The SP restaurant review writer didn't rename the files uploaded from their phone, leaving the "IMG_5611" at the start of the filename. This was enough to get them included in a copyright-related legal take down notice.

This arrived on a holiday and JRF was able to quickly respond and prevent others from wasting time on this...

From: Jeremy Farrance <jfarrance@accuraty.com>
Sent: Monday, September 01, 2025 10:09 AM
Subject: Fw: Google notice regarding copyright-related content
 
Please do not spend time on this unless you feel strongly there will be consequences for not responding to this notice. Thanks - Jeremy
 
 
PS, I do have to say, this is amazing. Took me a while to realize what is going on here.
 
The filename of the photo (photo added below since we currently have this type of direct-image hot-linking prevented)
https://www.smilepolitely.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/IMG_5611-Golden-Harbor.jpg

... the part highlighted is matching a filename in the list the lawyers were given. Since lots of people upload photos from their phones without renaming them, there are lots of photos on the Internet that contain "IMG_5611" in the filename. You can see 10s of thousands of them with a simple Google search. ALL these photos will match based on the way this claim was done.
 
So, this is frivolous and either lazy-lawyering or lawyers using A.I. or some other failure of the system.
 

IMG_5611-Golden-Harbor.jpg

If you are still reading and curious, this claim was started by a young lady using a law firm to try to undo all evidence of her previous online life (hint: OnlyFans).
Additional Consequences for NOT Renaming Files

Better coding is a lot of things and its a very personal experience sorting it out. It takes years of learning and choices.

This page is simply about revealing a few fundamentals that can help you avoid bad habits and out right mistakes.
Better Coding According to Accuraty 📐

What to embrace, even if it requires learning and rethinking: 

If you do not see how vibe coding can help you, 
you are not trying to learn and improve or 
you are not being very creative

When its a useful tool that saves developers time:

  • Using auto-complete, IntelliSense, and other (A.I. driven) suggestions in your text editor
  • Writing code and using A.I. as both a rubber duckie assistant and speed-learning super-docs reference machine

When its a fantasy that threatens developer jobs:

  • Creating apps and websites using plain English
  • Prompting an A.I. and using suggested code as-is

And yes, this applies to all code including HTML and CSS!

Please go read that second bullet under fantasy again. It is the best single thing to remember  and apply regularly in your everyday work from this topic.

The key take away here is that you still need to know how to code well, if you want to be a coder. Even if you code well, there is a lot of beneficial code that is not worth writing or reading - as long as you do not use it in production. Testing, learning, debugging, re-writing A.I. provided code can save time; in the hands of a non-beginner developer. Vibe coding can be great when you realize that throwing away a bad solution or idea wastes less time than spending hours coding a poor solution or idea that just doesn't properly work or fit the user's needs.

Do not let yourself be click-baited by stuff like this. He is talking about the fantasy, not the useful tool that A.I. is...
What "Vibe Coding" Means

Key Takeaway:

Though often expected and still "traditional" in recent memory, "All rights reserved" is not legally required (in 1989 the U.S. joined Berne, see Berne Convention, Paris Act, Article 5-2).

Interesting:

The company name should be identified "legally correct" in the copyright statement. Usually this is done by looking up the organization’s state regisistration and repeated exactly as presented there. For an Illinois business, go here, click Search, enter "Accuraty" and that is the exact legal name to use in the copyright.

Also, with the full legal company name in the footer (on the page), the full company name is not required in any other context except for specific legal statements (e.g. licensing info, etc.) So, with "Accuraty Solutions, LLC" in the copyright, we can refer to ourselves as Accuraty or Accuraty Solutions elsewhere as needed or preferred.

Bonus: 

Does case matter? No, letter casing does not affect the legal validity of a entity’s name, so we defer to the client preference or branding guide.

Remember: over 80% of what you need to know is CSS with reasonable knowledge of HTML. Tailwind is simply the a set of expressive utilities that allow you to do your CSS magic without leaving the work that is in front of you.

As such, its better to really learn CSS well and leave Tailwind learning to muscle memory by using it regularly. In other words, learn the CSS concepts well and you will naturally remember Tailwind by actual use and repetition.

The goal here is to take a DNN site from the default install with a single language all the way through to content on a page with two flags in the upper right allowing an anonymous visitor to switch between the content. Initial work-through was done for CETA2026.

Tags: Localization, French, Français, Canada, multilanguage
DNN Multiple Language Setup Walkthrough

Before starting, you need to confirm what languages you need. Also, ask yourself if the languages are on every page or if a few pages should not be translated.

This example will use en-US (default at the start) and fr-CA as our languages. Its also important to ask and consider whether or not you should use an English variant. For example, in Canada its likely the client would expect the default to be en-CA instead of en-US.

Step 1 - DNN Settings

  • Go to your DNN website and log in as an Host/Super [does this work per-portal for Admin?]
  • Site Settings > Languages > Add New Language > Francais (Canada) > SAVE
  • Languages > Culture table > Francais (Canada) row > click on paper with the translate symbol icon
  • Translate Page Content: Activate Pages in This Language = ON
    • This allows the flags to display for choosing a language
  • Languages > Settings
    • Enable Language Parameter in URLS = On by default?
    • Enable Browser Language Detection = On
    • Users May Choose Interface Language = On
    • Allow Content Localization = On > Save
    • Click the Enable Localized Content > Save 
  • Page Settings > Home page > Localization tab > click "Add Missing Language" button
    • You should see all your languages in columns
    • Also, every new page should pick up all your languages moving forward
  • Click "Update Localization"
    • This can take a while, so you must wait for it to complete this step. Currently, unsure how you would know when this is done because there is no progress/tracker

Step 2 - VS Code

  • This is for AccuTheme, Xcillion has styles already in place
  • Create a branch to add code and styles for the flags
  • Locate the includes > _registers.ascx file to confirm the TagName="LANGUAGE" line is there
    • <%@ Register TagPrefix="dnn" TagName="LANGUAGE" Src="~/Admin/Skins/Language.ascx" %> >
  • Locate the includes > _header.ascx file, so that we can add code to the navbar or eyebrow.
  • <div class="language"/><dnn:LANGUAGE runat="server" ID="LANGUAGE1" ShowMenu="False" ShowLinks="True" /></div >
  • For Bootstrap
    • Add styles in the _header.scss file. Below is basic and can be changed per project. 
      .language {
  display: inline-block;
  align-self: center;

  .language-object {
    display: block;
    margin: 0;
    padding: 0;

    span {
      padding-right: 1rem;

      &:last-child {
        padding-right: 0;
      }
    }
  }
}
  • For Tailwind
    • No example at this time

Step 3 - 2sxc

  • These steps are assuming that 2sxc is already installed
  • Add a 2sxc module to the page
  • Spin the module settings and select Manage Apps
  • Click the Languages in the tab navigation
  • For all languages, turn the Status toggle to ON
  • Close the window and refresh the page
  • Edit the Content module as English (default language) first
    • You should see the languages at the top of the edit window
  • Fill out your fields as English is selected > Save
  • Page Settings > Localization > make sure the columns only have one Content module, and the other languages say "Copy Module" > Check them > Update Localization
  • Select a different flag to see if the module copied over
  • Edit the module > confirm language is right at the top > Translate > Translate all
  • Fill out your fields in the corresponding language > Save
  • Test by selecting the US flag and clicking edit on the module > select the other language to see if it is still the same > leave editor
  • Page Settings > Localization > in the other language, the copied module should now be in the corresponding language

Using Tailwind CSS v4+ from the ground up with a clear set of foundational ideas and patterns will dramatically minimize building and maintaining projects on a team and over long periods of time.
Using Tailwind v4.1+ Correctly and As-Intended

Warning: any solution presented via Google or A.I. that is talking about tailwind.config.js is out of date. Though it may contain clues and use the correct terminology, we embrace CSS-first configuration. Stop and update your question to more clearly specify that you want a Tailwind v4 answer.

Reminder: though @apply is still supported in v4, the recommendation from the TailwindCss team is to not (almost never) use it... In Tw, we embrace utility-first classes and @apply is the opposite. If your brain is pretty sure this is wrong, please stop, go to Google, enter "though still support, usage of @apply in Tailwind v4 is discouraged, why?" and start reading and keep reading until you understand. Note that we do use @apply in a few places in AccuTheme-Tw4, this is because, especially in a theme, there are situations where its usefulness out-weighs the reasons not to use it. As a padawan, please do not use it until you clearly learn exactly when and why it might make sense.
Learn or unlearn, but get there quickly...

Correct usage results in an very optimized experience from building (developer/designer and content creator) to the users of websites and apps.

Jeremy's version is simple: anything that loads into your device once and is re-used (cached) is the best possible user experience...

A properly setup DNN website will do an excellent job sending /Skin.css?cdv=nnn, where it can be re-used across the site for every page from the browser's cache. This is why AccuTheme builds almost everything into that single file. Tailwind - again, when used correctly - optimizes your CSS down to the smallest possible size not only at compile-time (go lookup CSS tree-shaking), but also in its core principle design choices. 

Exceptions? Sure. For example, as AccuTheme-Tw4 reaches 1.0 it includes some learning-laziness (the Accuraty team has been using Bootstrap for at least 10 years). There is a file in place in the CSS config named bs5-favs.css. It commits two crimes, 1) uses @apply and 2) though they are utility classes, they are very clearly not utility-first. At launch, we got this file down to just basic alerts, but it is still hypocracy. 🥹
Core principles for using Tailwind v4

This is the central tenet of Tailwind. For elements with unique spacing, layout, color, and responsiveness, apply utilities directly in your HTML or component markup.

When to use: Use utility classes for styling most elements on a page, especially for layout, spacing, typography, and colors.

Best practice: When you find yourself overriding styles frequently in different places, it's a "code smell" that suggests those styles should be utility classes instead of a custom class. Example:

<div class="flex items-center justify-between p-4 bg-gray-100 dark:bg-gray-800">
  <h1 class="text-xl font-bold text-gray-900 dark:text-gray-100">My App</h1>
  <button class="px-4 py-2 text-white rounded-lg bg-sky-500 hover:bg-sky-700">Click Me</button>
</div>
Prioritize utility classes for most styling

For common, reusable UI elements like buttons, badges, or form inputs, group utility classes into a new component class. For example:

.btn-primary {
  @apply rounded-lg bg-sky-500 px-4 py-2 text-white hover:bg-sky-700;
}

Used in HTML:

<button class="btn-primary">Submit</button>

Note: this could be an example of when to break the don't use @apply rule. There are situation in a theme where it could make sense, but this is rarely the case when styling content. Make sure you are always aware of what level you are styling at: theme, components, content, etc.
Abstract repeated patterns with component classes

Tailwind v4 moves theme customization and extensions into your main CSS file using new @ directives, deprecating the automatic tailwind.config.js file. For example:

Use the @theme directive to define CSS custom properties (variables) for your design system. These variables can then be used by Tailwind's generated utilities.

@import "tailwindcss";

@theme {
  --font-sans: "Inter", sans-serif;
  --color-brand: oklch(0.637 0.237 25.331);
}

Using this in your theme:

<h1 class="font-sans text-[var(--color-brand)]">Hello, World!</h1>
Embrace CSS-first configuration

The rewritten engine allows for more powerful and flexible variant combinations. You can now compose variants like group-* and peer-* with states like hover and new variants like not-*.

<div class="group">
  <div class="group-hover:opacity-100 group-not-has-[.has-alert]:hidden">
    <!-- Content -->
  </div>
</div>
Leverage composable variants

The more you know about Tailwind, the better you can acheive the principles and goals. Once you are comfortable with the basics and have a few dozen utilties at your fingertips from memory, you should probably start either diving deeper into the ones you already know or learning new ones. 

The goal of this page is to simply list each topic and link you to 1) the docs, 2) a recommended video, 3) a Tw Play experiment, and 4) where to go for a deeper dive.

Example of a typical error:

[FileLoadException: Could not load file or assembly 'System.Memory' or one of its dependencies. 
The located assembly's manifest definition does not match the assembly reference. 
(Exception from HRESULT: 0x80131040)]

This happens during the ASP.NET app's startup. It is basically loading web.config and checking that everything (dependencies) are found, valid, and the expected versions are correct.

Above is specifically telling you System.Memory is different than what it expected; the located assembly's manifest definition (inside the DLL its looking at) does not match the assembly reference (what the code that was planning to call into it was expecting at compile). Please read this paragraph again if it doesn't make complete sense yet. It should.
Assembly Reference Errors

You have to see the real error. This applies when DNN fails to start during its parsing of web.config. Under default configuration, IIS and your web.config file will NOT show you the "yellow page of death" (with the real error) unless you are local; you have to be on the machine hosting the site. **

When viewing DLLs in the /bin folder in Windows File Explorer, you can and should add a column so you can easily see the actual version. To do this, in Explorer in the column header row (Name, Date modified, etc), right-click, More... scoll and find "File version", check, save. See pic at left.
The most important tools to keep you focused on the right details

First, stay focused on the error. There could be many errors, but you usually want to fix the one that is displaying. The first thing to note is which DLL. If the error is about "System.Memory" you should probably expect to be finding a matching file named, "System.Memory.dll". Don't assume there is only one, check subfolders!

Second, make note of the File Version. There is usually only the one in /bin, but if there are versions in subfolders, make note of those file versions too.

Now that you know these two things, does the Binding Redirect's target match the File Version?

If no, now you have things to try.

  1. edit web.config so that the target matches the file version
  2. find the right DLL with the specified file version and copy it over (replace) the existing one

Immediately reload the page and see if things have changed.

Important: read the error carefully after the reload. Sometimes you have fixed the error and its now displaying another, similar one.
The First and Second Things to Check

Web.config is just a text file. Your project has a bad one that is resulting in an error at startup? Find a copy of a working web.config file from when the site worked. You have a backup from before you installed the module that broke it? Open the backup, get the web.config file, rename it to something like, "web-working.config" and then use a Diff Tool to compare the bad one and the good one. The text editor VS Code has a nice diff tool built in and you can right-click on the good web.config, choose Select for Compare, then right-click on the bad one and choose Compare with Selected. Now you can "see" the differences and greatly narrow down the answer to "what changed and broke it?"
Compare Good and Bad Web.config Files

Updated 20250502 JRF

<dependentAssembly xmlns="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:asm.v1">
  <assemblyIdentity name="System.Runtime.CompilerServices.Unsafe" publicKeyToken="b03f5f7f11d50a3a" />
  <bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-4.0.4.1" newVersion="4.0.4.1" xmlns="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:asm.v1" />
  <codeBase version="4.0.4.1" href="bin\Imageflow\System.Runtime.CompilerServices.Unsafe.dll" xmlns="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:asm.v1" />
  <bindingRedirect oldVersion="4.0.4.2-32767.32767.32767.32767" newVersion="6.0.0.0" />
</dependentAssembly>

In English, the above says

For System.Runtime.CompilerServices.Unsafe dll
1. any version expecting anything up to v4.0.4.1, your target is 4.0.4.1 (and is in the default location; /bin or up in .NET)
2. any version above that (4.0.4.2+), your target is 6.0.0.0 which is in /bin/Imageflow

To see cool/complex examples of Binding Redirects, open DNN's web.config after 2sxc is installed and note the ones with multiple version ranges and multiple DLLs in subfolders. Above is an example from dnn91200 and then installing 2sxc v16.7.0.

Also, do not assume DNN's or the vendor's additions to web.config are correct. Startup can be forgiving and work even when the wrong versions are specified. Then they break later when a DLL is added that is different or simply wasn't there before. 

If you are still unclear on the concept, sometimes it helps to read a different explanation. Check out this help Q&A from StackOverflow.
Understand What BindingRedirect Does

First, take a break. 20 or 30 minutes away from the problem. Then come back. Start at the beginning again. Avoid assumptions, "I know the error is because Newtonsoft's DLL is older." Instead, go to the file, look at the File Version! Assumptions are bad.

Consider using a tool like nvQuickSite to locally install the same version of DNN and all the modules that might be involved in the problem. The key here is making sure every version is identical to the project with problem. Assuming the locally installed version is working and your project is not, you now have a web.config and /bin folder to compare with. In this situation, having a powerful compare ("diffing") tool is incredibly imporant and time saving; recommended one is Beyond Compare. Not free, but if its a new install, it works for 30 days and can help you right now!

Note that if you install DNN and identical modules and your new local instance has the error or any errors after a module install, then you probably have a real bug and need to contact the vendor of the module to report it or get assistance.

If hours have gone by, remember that this stuff can be hard and confusing. Reach out to someone for help.
When things get Confusing or Difficult

Its important to realize your ASP.NET app not only has DLLs in its /bin folder, but is also looking at all of the .NET Framework and/or .NET Core the various parts were built and compiled with.

** For those people that host their site in places where they cannot view the error locally (shared hosting, etc.), here are some ways to see the error.

  • if you already have a backup module installed (e.g. Evotiva DNN Backup) and you have access to a local machine or workstation with IIS and MSSQL on it (or nearby), you can get a copy of the site restored and spun up
  • ask your host to do it for you; browse the site on the server (not always possible)
  • if you do have access to modify the site's web.config, you can temporarily allow these errors to be visible publicly [TODO add (link to?) how-to]

Things you don't know or will forget until your stuff is not working the way you expect.

This is a WIP start of a page that will better define the problem and show the best or Accuraty's chosen solution.

Duplicates without User-Selected Canonical on pages with combinable filters in URL parameters...

The Problem

A simple example is shown here:


https://www.cuaerospace.com/publications-presentations/publication-articles/author/2186/year/2025
https://www.cuaerospace.com/publications-presentations/publication-articles/year/2025/author/2186

Note: whether or not these links return results or not, has nothing to do with the problem.

The problem is that both pages return the exact same results and Google or other crawlers will often "walk" your HTML elements (select/options) across all possible combinations to make sure they've found everything that needs indexing.

So the problem from the crawler's point of view is these two links point to the same page. More specifically, these two URLs returns the same HTML results.

The Solution

In this case, Google is being pretty helpful, the solution is in the error statement. We need to add a Canonical statement to the page. In other words, the HTML standard has a way to add this to the page in the header so that both pages will be able to properly report their one real, only, and correct URL to use.

You can see an extreme version of this on our CPHP2022 project.

Finding the Hidden Things in 2sxc - there are many items that existing and are useful, but VERY difficult to find or even become aware of. Some examples are default Image settings, settings for Views, etc.
Where is it?

Getting to them in your App's Admin UI is very easy and logical. Getting there from code is an excellent example of why this page exists. The actual settings you save when you are in the UI in the View Configuration (name, template file, content item, etc.) are saved to Content Type:

[App] > Admin > Data, at the bottom of the UI change Scope (from Default) to System.Cms and then you should see one named View Configuration.
2sxc View Settings: Where is the data stored?

This is unusually hard to grok without knowing the info above (where its stored). Now that you know its just another Content Type, that means it has an .Id and a .Guid and you can get both of these by opening the View Configuration records (3) above.

We'll use the .Id and hopefully this code makes things obvious...

How to get the Path and Filename of the Razor Code File (*.cshtml)

What is our use-case? Simple, Accuraty standards prefer that when we have a JS or CSS file to attach, that we name it identical to the View's razor filename.

This is the updated answer (20250109). The info below the line was the original answer. Please let it here as both are useful and informative in understanding 2sxc's App.Data.

@{
  // this is a newer, less-code, more direct way to get the View's Path+Filename
  // see https://stackoverflow.com/questions/79322437
  var myViewSettings = App.Data.GetOne<Custom.Data.CustomItem>(MyView.Id, skipTypeCheck: true); 
 
  // now we can get the Path with @myViewSettings.String("Path")
  // result: "Link__Yellow--tawk-jsapi-activity.cshtml"
  // and now we can attach Link__Yellow--tawk-jsapi-experiments.js or .css if needed!
}

Note this example shows only the filename returned, but the path will come into play if you have your file in a subfolder. The key thing to remember is that you are in the app's root (cwd).

Slightly older answer using the View Configuration's internal Content Type name with GetStream()

There is probably a better way, but this works. Please see the StackOverflow Question and Answers for more details or (someday) a better answer.

Since MyView (ICmsView) does not return the filename in any way (that I could figure out as of 20250108), we instead go under the hood and get the raw Entity from the (internal name of the) Content Type used for the View Settings you edit/save via the UI: "2SexyContent-Template" and the .Id of it comes from MyView.Id.

@{
  // this is our less-than-ideal way to get the View's Path+Filename
  // see https://stackoverflow.com/questions/79322437
  var myViewSettings = AsItem(App.Data.GetStream(name: "2SexyContent-Template")
    .Where(t => t.EntityId == MyView.Id)
    .FirstOrDefault()
  );
  // now we can get the Path with @myViewSettings.String("Path")
  // result: "FCTRL/Link__Yellow--tawk-jsapi-experiments.cshtml"
  // and now we can attach Link__Yellow--tawk-jsapi-experiments.js or .css if needed!
}
  • Related Documentation: CustomItem, View Configuration
  • Tags: view settings, razor code file, path filename

Lots of fantastic examples are in the official 2sxc Tutorials. The documentation is here for the Toolbar Builder and Tweak(ing). In the field, we've spotted use cases that aren't covered (e.g. a good Prefill example), so we've got some of our own below.

  • WIP/IDEA: need visual quick reference for ALL the possible Toolbar buttons

2sxc Toolbar Examples

This turned out to be so easy I thought I'd share it here. I may not win any awards for the two icons I chose, but they do sort of communicate the toggle between 1) pinning the current image to repeat on page load vs 2) shuffle; so next page loads 1 of N images.

Step one is to go find your HTML code for your symbol. I used this site and found die-face-1 (\2680) and die-face-5 (\2684). Yes, a little square dice face.

Then added the following to CSS classes to be available to the page/module.


/* die-face-1: '⚀'  - https://www.toptal.com/designers/htmlarrows/symbols/die-face-1/ */
.icon-sxc-die-one::before {
  content: "\2680";
}

/* die-face-5: '⚄' - https://www.toptal.com/designers/htmlarrows/symbols/die-face-5/ */
.icon-sxc-die-five::before {
  content: "\2684";
}

Then my Razor code simply defined an empty Toolbar, added an Info() button tweaking the Ui() so the title attr shows a useful tooltip on hover and then we set the Icon() class we set above.

  @if( MyUser.IsContentAdmin )
  {
    string label = $"Pin {banner.Id}";
    var PinToolbar = Kit.Toolbar.Empty()
      .Info(link: Link.To(parameters: MyPage.Parameters.Set("pin", banner.Id)), 
        tweak: b => b.Note("Pin current photo")
          .Ui("title", $"That number ({banner.Id}) is the current banner Id")
          .Icon("icon-sxc-die-one")
      )
      .Settings(show: "always")
    ; 
    if ( pinnedBannerId > 0 )
    {
      label = $"Unpin {pinnedBannerId}";
      PinToolbar = Kit.Toolbar.Empty()
        .Info(
          link: Link.To(parameters: MyPage.Parameters.Flush()),
          tweak: b => b
            // .Ui("title", "Clear the URL params and go back to Sequential banner rotation on page reload")
            .Ui("title", "Clear the URL params and go back to Shuffled-Random banner photo on page reload")
            .Icon("icon-sxc-die-five")
        )
        .Settings(show: "always")
      ;
    }
    <div class="alert alert-light position-absolute p-1 m-0" style="z-index:1;bottom:1rem;left:1rem;opacity:0.75;" @PinToolbar>
      <code class="" style="padding-right:2rem;">@($"{label}:") </code>
    </div>
  }
How to I Set a Custom Icon in a 2sxc Toolbar

Toolbar: Add Class(es)
<div id="hero-banner-@Kit.Key.UniqueKey" 
  class="co-header mb-custom" 
  @Kit.Toolbar.Default(MyItem).Settings(classes: "mt-5")
>

@inherits Custom.Hybrid.RazorTyped

<div class="alert alert-light"
  @Kit.Toolbar.Default(MyItem).Settings(autoAddMore: "end", hover: "left")>
  <h3>New syntax: Hover Left and 
    <code>more</code> button to the right
  </h3>
</div>
Toolbar: Show Always and Add a Class of margin-top with negative margin to position it unobstructively (see pic at right)
<div class="img-fluid" @Kit.Toolbar.Default(MyItem).Settings(show: "always", classes: "mt-n4)>
  ...
</div>

Inside a foreach loop with a lot of items. A few need an extra Toolbar Button sometimes. And this button needs to take the user to another page to manage related data so the URL needs a parameter with an item ID.

Note: this solution is a hack to solve for the problem where the .Info() link only opens in a new window in v16. In v17, they added the target param, so .Info(link: "...", target: "_blank")

Using the Toolbar Building fluent functions, .Code() does what the older toolbar technologies called custom. So to start, we need a JS function, this will have the item passed to it (not an ID, the whole object; context).
Calling JavaScript Function and using a Prepared Ui

<script>
  function navigateToAssignUsers(context, event) {
    var pageId = @assignUsersPageId; 
    window.location.href = `/tabid/${pageId}/itemId/${context.entityId}`; // Redirects the user to the new URL
  }
</script>

The JS code above appears on the page, but before its sent to the browser, @assignUsersPageId will get replaced with the pageId.

So, inside our foreach loop through our items, most only need an .Edit() button. However, some of the Items have a field named RuleType that is a string dropdown. Default it empty, but when the RuleType is set to "users" we need to add the extra button.

As a bonus, this example is using the newer v14+ feature where we can inline our own SVG icon. So lets declare that first along with our assignUsersPageId that we'll need to replace in our JS:

  const int assignUsersPageId = 176;
  const string svgIcon = "<svg width='36px' height='36px' viewBox='0 0 36 36' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><defs><style>.cls-1{fill:none;stroke:#000000;stroke-linecap:round;stroke-linejoin:round;stroke-width:2px;}</style></defs><title/><g data-name='79-users' id='_79-users'><circle class='cls-1' cx='16' cy='13' r='5'/><path class='cls-1' d='M23,28A7,7,0,0,0,9,28Z'/><path class='cls-1' d='M24,14a5,5,0,1,0-4-8'/><path class='cls-1' d='M25,24h6a7,7,0,0,0-7-7'/><path class='cls-1' d='M12,6a5,5,0,1,0-4,8'/><path class='cls-1' d='M8,17a7,7,0,0,0-7,7H7'/></g></svg>";

We'll establish our very readable Ui settings as an anonymous type:

  var uiCode = new { 
    Icon = svgIcon,
    Title = "Assign Users",
    Color = "purple"
  };

Then we prep our reusable edit button, already targeting the item:

  var tbEdit = Kit.Toolbar.Empty(item).Edit();

And now, inside the wrapping html item (a span in this case), we inject the toolbar attributes:

  <span class="mx-2"
    @((item.String("RuleType") == "users")
      ? tbEdit.Code(target: "navigateToAssignUsers", ui: uiCode)
      : tbEdit
    )
  >
    @item.String("Name") 
  </span>

Notice that the .Code() only needs to know the name of the function (the target). We don't have to setup parameters (e.g. pass in an item.Id) because the 2sxc is going to pass "the context" which in this case, is the item. So the item.Id we need, once inside the JS function is now context.entityId.
Calling JavaScript Function and using ... (cont'd)

In this unique case we had a lot of fields that needed to be prefilled when creating the new item and could not expect the user to fill things out correctly or consistently. See the screenshot at right.

In addition, since the feature is seldom used, we wanted to be very clear in reminding the editor what is going on without cluttering up the UI. So if they pause and hover on the button (see screenshot below), you get a simple HTML tooltip thanks to the Title attribute.

Important: since 2sxc v14, prefill has supported being set as an object. We greatly prefer this because the code is more readable. See `prepPrefill` below. 

Note: this looks a bit crazy, but its fairly readable (when formatted well). To summarize we are just creating two buttons (highlighted), the first (a .Info()) with help/reminders and the second (a .New()) with lots of prefill data.
Prefill, Tweak, and Useful Hover Details

Reminder: the code example above uses String Interpolation. Prior to DNN v10 CodeDom was optional. If you are getting an error about the dollar signs ("$"), it means you do not have CodeDom installed. CodeDom: What, Where, How to?
CodeDom, C# 8.0 and Higher

Opinion: the key to keeping these readable and therefore maintainable is in sticking to the new object notation as much as possible. Almost everything you need to do is now covered by these two interfaces: IToolbarBuilder and ITweakButton.

if (IsSiteManager)
{
  string prepNameField = $"{Dept.Title} at {Loc.Title}";
  var prepPrefill = new { 
    Name = prepNameField,
    Parent = Dept.EntityGuid,
    Child = Loc.EntityGuid,
    TitleCustom = Loc.Title,
    TitleSmallCustom = Dept.Title
  };
  var prepToolbar = Kit.Toolbar.Empty()
    .Info(
      link: "/tabid/154", 
      tweak: b => b
      .Note(
        note: "Click here for a brief explanation of how this special Department + Location content works",
        background: "#008ece20"
      )
      .Color(
        background: "#008ece",
        foreground: "white"
      )
      .Ui("title", "Help and Reminders")
    )
    .New(
      target: "AssociativeDetails",
      tweak: b => b
      .Ui(new { 
        title = $"Add extra details for: {prepNameField}",
        color = "green"
        }
      )
      .Classes("mr-n1")
      .Prefill(prepPrefill)
    )
  ;
  <div class="alert alert-primary" role="alert" 
    title="This box is only visible to editors, see Help"
    @prepToolbar
  >
    No associative details have been added yet for this Dept+Loc.
  </div>
}
Prefill, Tweak, and Useful Hover Details... cont'd

DNN Keeps separate Permissions for each Language. For a beginner, it is not obvious. Below is a screen shot of Page Settings for the en-US version of the page. The arrow shows how to switch to the fr-CA Page Settings.

After you click the gear, the page will reload and the PersonaBar will re-open and you are now on the Page Settings for the fr-CA language page.

As you can see below, to switch back, there is now a gear icon on the Localization en-US card.
But Wait, There is More - Per Language Page Permissions

Good learning and realization comments from Aaron at Wolf X Machina.

  • did you know that you can actually re-order pages differently between languages?
  • you can have completely separate modules with separate content on a localized page
  • one of the best things you can do to prevent confusion is very carefully name your Module Titles, follow a pattern or make a plan

Common things that go wrong later on.

  • instead of translating a module (the correct way), a user might just add a new module and then wonder why it doesn’t show up on the other language page
  • a user adds 1 module for each Page+Language and then also has all languages manage again for each module

Another useful tip...

If you have a website that has two languages, but it ALSO has 2 different domains like myenglishsite.ca and monfrancaissite.ca, you can set the primary alias on multiple websites and set the Site Alias Mapping Mode to redirect. So my site that has that has myenglishsite.ca , myenglishsite.ca/en-ca, and monfrancaissite.ca all with the checkmarks for "primary alias" beside them.

And so when the user clicks the language toggle, it flips them between domains
Edge Cases from the Great White North

IIS (and DNN) can be setup to allow very large file uploads. We have successfully configured (in the IIS 10 and DNN 9.2 era) and gotten DVD .iso files slightly over 4 GBs to work.

In brief, there are 3 aspects: max file size, threshold (buffer), and time. The latter is the one that most people miss initially - if your executionTimeout doesn't allow enough time at the (user to server) connection speed, the upload will fail.

Once you set the max file size above 64 MBs (opinions vary, but this is still a good baseline in 2025) you need to be very aware of the threshold (buffer). Once the upload starts streaming to the server, this value does two important things: 1) its the amount of RAM allocated and 2) each time the buffer fills, this chunk of the upload is written to disk and the buffer is cleared. Both too small and too large a threshold can cause issues.
DNN Large File Upload Requires web.config Changes

executionTimeout = seconds
maxRequestLength = Kb
requestLengthDiskThreshold = Kb
maxAllowedContentLength = bytes
Reminders on Parameter Units

Here are DNN v10.01 era defaults from web.config:

<httpRuntime targetFramework="4.7.2" shutdownTimeout="120" executionTimeout="1200" useFullyQualifiedRedirectUrl="true" 
maxRequestLength="28672" requestLengthDiskThreshold="81920" maxUrlLength="2048" 
requestPathInvalidCharacters="<,>,*,%,:,\,?" enableVersionHeader="false"  
requestValidationMode="2.0" fcnMode="Single" />

and under <system.webServer>

<security>
  <requestFiltering>
    <requestLimits maxAllowedContentLength="29360128" />
  </requestFiltering>
</security>

Note from JRF

The DNN settings above are incorrect and in our projects (via AccuClone deploy), we have threshold properly set to 28672. Someday it will get fixed in DNN. Worse, the MS Docs are wrong too. Updated 20251018 JRF, Updated 20230803 JRF (See DNN #5778)
DNN v10.01.x Defaults (2025)

Note that maxRequestLength has a 2 GB max in 32bit ASP.NET. Accuraty is 100% 64bit as a 2023Q4, but leaving this not here for others.

<httpRuntime targetFramework="4.7.2" shutdownTimeout="120" executionTimeout="3600" useFullyQualifiedRedirectUrl="true" 
maxRequestLength="1572864" requestLengthDiskThreshold="1024" maxUrlLength="2048" 
requestPathInvalidCharacters="<,>,*,%,:,\,?" enableVersionHeader="false"  
requestValidationMode="2.0" fcnMode="Single" />

and under <system.webServer> (below you see 1.5 GBs in bytes, above is KB)

<security>
  <requestFiltering>
    <requestLimits maxAllowedContentLength="1610612736" />
  </requestFiltering>
</security>
Example for Max File Size of 1.5 GBs (1,536 MBs) with 60 min timeout and 1 MB threshold

GH/DNN Issue# 6816 [Bug]: requestLengthDiskThreshold is incorrectly configured

GH/DNN Issue# 5778 [Bug]: Setting the Max Upload Size (MB) results in unexpected

DNN Documention Center (2017 and earlier): How to Increase the Maximum File Size for Upload

Aspdotnet-Sharepoint (2012 via Wayback): how to increase the maximum file upload size in dnn
Related Information
Starters are stripped down examples for Page, Layout, Structure, Lists, and more. They are functional shells and ready for styling (and populating with data).
Overview: Starters and other Tailwind Css Primitives

The "category language" we use is specific to the way AccuTheme (and DNN) guide you in building pages.

Skins - these are the entry point wrappers that establish your page's HTML. Though the output is constrained to being inside the <body>, there are tools to register scripts and styles (with options to preload, and target them for <head>, body, or bottom/footer.

Panes - these are Page Sections and (for DNN) the insertion points for Modules in the Skin.

  • Rows - though not enforced, AccuTheme is generally designed around the idea (and expecting) that a Pane is an entire row on the page. CSS and the Module will decide how to divide up the content into columns or not. Rules were made to be broken and there are valid cases for having, for example, a 50:50 set of Panes on a Row.

Containers - though they still exist, these DNN Module wrappers are not used in AccuTheme. The Module is responsible for its Title and the DNN Module Settings like Title are only used in support of the Content Editor, Developer, Admin, etc.
Putting DNN in its Place

Structures - full page structures with the immediate children being <header>, <main>, and <footer>.

List Layouts - think of these as being inside the module and providing a header and footer with repeating (foreach) content elements (Cards) in between.

Detail Layouts - think of these are the repeating content elements in the List Layout. We will often refer to these are Cards or Articles.

DNN Development Setup

Do not proceed...

Do not proceed past here unless you've really completed all steps in Building Dnn. Note that this means you actually did a sucessful build... this is required to have occurred for a lot of the things below to work, build, etc.

Overview

  • Step 20 is referring to this, DNN Platform Developer Quick Start Step-By-Step
  • We use Visual Studio (Latest, VS2022 v17.11.x last time this was updated).
  • The VS solution root is C:\dev\Dnn.Platform\ {here}
  • The nvQuickSite deployed live DNN instance that you
    • run (and build/compile into) is C:\dev\dnn\vs09\ {here}
    • with URL https://vs09.dnndev.me
    • and the database name (our standard) should include the DNN version like this dnn09vs

Details

At Accuraty we prefer to do the initial dev site install using nvQuickSite. So, when you get to step 20, for local dev we prefer to stick with the trusted connections (not create a separate re-used SQL user), so here are some notes on how to use the App Pool User.

Notes:

  • we use the public *.dnndev.me so you can skip step 22 (hosts file DNS override)
  • running ResetDevSite (step 23) takes about 2 mins on a fast machine, 4-7 mins on an average machine, and much longer (20+ mins) on older machines with non-SSD hard drives
  • disable Caching in your browser when working on the site; you should have DevTools open and in the Network tab, disable the cache 
settings.local.json ( \Dnn.Platform\ )

Triple check that the highlighted items match your actual setup.

{
  "WebsitePath": "C:\\dev\\dnn\\vs09\\Website",
  "WebsiteUrl": "https://vs09.dnndev.me",
  "SaConnectionString": "server=(local);Trusted_Connection=True;",
  "DnnConnectionString": "Data Source=(local);Initial Catalog=dnn09vs;Integrated Security=True",
  "DbOwner": "dbo",
  "ObjectQualifier": "",
  "DnnDatabaseName": "dnn09vs",
  "DnnSqlUsername": "IIS APPPOOL\\vs09.dnndev.me_nvQuickSite",
  "DatabasePath": "C:\\dev\\dnn\\vs09\\Database",
  "Version": "auto"
}
DNN_Platform.local.build
<Project ToolsVersion="4.0" DefaultTargets="Build" xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/developer/msbuild/2003">
  <PropertyGroup>
    <WebsitePath Condition=" '$(Configuration)|$(Platform)' == 'Debug|AnyCPU' ">C:\dev\dnn\vs09\Website</WebsitePath>
  </PropertyGroup>
</Project>

The above setup allows you to run --target=ResetDevSite again for a completely clean local install based on your at-the-moment develop branch. This means your site is wiped and next time you reload vs.dnndev.me, you will be presented with the DNN Installation UI.
Create Local Settings - Starting at Step 20 (from above)

nvquickSITE Settings

The general idea here is that your Visual Studio development work on/in DNN might change over time, but an initial install using nvQuickSite only needs to be done once. Then just follow the setup below so you can easily do a full Dev Reset of the site when needed with almost no extra steps.

See image at right for the Site Info.

Note: the use case here is specific to situations where you are modifying a subproject (or workspace) within DNN. If your changes are broader and you are working on something that affects multiple parts of the project or the core DLLs, then you should instead use the command line build with --DevReset.
