Cliff notes by example. Use YARN not NPM.

I wanted to make a change in PersonaBar, Settings, Servers. Then under System Info, Web (subtab), I wanted to add NETFrameworkVersion to that output. See image at right.

This assumes DNN is Deployed per above, the Build works, and there is a local dev/staging site running and pointed to in settings.local.json

Find the project folder for the desired PersonaBar component. These folders usually end in ".Web" and though not visible in VS Solution Explorer, if you go to the Windows File Exporer and navigate to ... \Dnn.Platform\Dnn.AdminExperience\ClientSide\, we are looking for Servers.Web. In DNN for superusers, this is the output for PersonaBar, Settings, Servers. In that folder, we see "Servers.Web" - this is the folder we open in VS Code (as our project root).

Watch

Then there are two ways to start the "watch" so you can make changes and get a recompile on save. For reload, you should have DevTools open and cache disabled (in the Network tab).

The recommended way is to open a Terminal and cd to the Dnn.Platform/ root. Then (for Servers) you'd run:

  > yarn watch --scope servers

WIP: Another option (discovered by JRF and seems to work well) is to simply open the Terminal in VS Code. Accuraty settings means we default to PowerShell 7+. This opens rooted in .\ClientSide\Servers.Web\, and this command works from here:

  > yarn workspace servers watch

When work is done, to do the final non-debug (production) compile, use: 'build' instead of 'watch'.

For other workspaces see Servers.Web\package.json. Or use this command:

  yarn workspaces list

Note: since this change involved adding new items to (... \Dnn.Platform \Dnn.AdminExperience \Dnn.PersonaBar.Extensions \admin \personaBar \Dnn.Servers \App_LocalResources) \Servers.resx, back in Visual Studio, this requires a recompile on the backend. But we can just recompile this one project. To do that, in Solution Explorer, drill down to Dnn.AdminExperience, Extensions, Dnn.PersonBar.Extensions. This is the project, right-click it and Rebuild. The Output panel should start spewing until finished.

Assuming both projects compiled without error, you should be able to go to your local DNN dev site, Settings/Servers/Restart Application, then navigate to to the Web subtab and see the updated results (example image at right is from this change in v9.13.5).
How to Change and Rebuild PersonaBar Components

A cool trick from Daniel Valadas. In VS with DNN Platform solution loaded, in Solution Explorer, expand DNN Platform, right-click the Build node (see image at right) and select Set as Startup Project. Now you can launch the full DNN solution Build with the normal VS button. You will get a command line window popup showing you the output (and a Diagnostic Tools panel).

This was started as an idea and thought experiment the day Theo's video, My Current Stack debuted on YouTube - Apr 4, 2025

Some rules to follow:

  1. Complexity is the enemy
  2. Data will never exist in two places, if/when it does, fix it now, don't wait
  3. Understand what your app is (what problems it solves), what the users need, and take into account the scale
  4. Start with the simplest things (and know which ones will be affected by complexity)
  5. Add complexity as (when) necessary >>> do not convert content to data+views when its only updated yearly or never
  6. Re-evaluate your choices at least yearly to either remove the complexity OR add it when it is the right solution to a problem

"Complexity is the enemy of success and scale." - Theo
An Experiment in Comparing DNN to a Modern Stack - Apr 2025

Overnitesend says

What to do when we get told that one of our businesses/profiles has been suspended.

Important: Once you start the Appeal, you only have 60 minutes to submit your evidence/documents. These documents should have your business name and address.

Evidence/Documents to Ask the Client for:

  • Official business registration
  • A business license
  • Tax certificates
  • Utility bills (electricity, phone, cable, internet, etc) for the business

Photos:

  • A photo from the exterior of the building will strengthen the case
  • A photo of the permanent signage will help

Appeal Steps:

  1. Once all of the documents listed above have been gathered, put them in a ZIP folder
  2. Review the Google Profile for the particular client marked for suspension. Continue only if you are 100% certain that all the fields for the profile follow Google's Policies.
  3. Start the Appeal process for the particular client
  4. Attached the ZIP folder
  5. Add additional comments to support your claim
  6. You will be redirected to the Appeal start page to see the status
  7. You will receive an email if your business appeal was approved

Note: It might take a few days after getting reclaimed to rank as high as you were before the suspension.

 

Email to client example for getting documents and photo(s). We do not want to mention that their account was suspended. Rather, we will want to mention that Google needs to verify the client account.

Hi [ Primary Contact Name ],

Google sent the second wave of verification for us to complete for [ Company Name ]. This involves a copy of Utility bills (electricity, phone, cable, internet, etc.) for the business. They must be under the business's name (not your name or any other staff), and the address should match what is listed for the business [business's address ].
 
The Utility bills are the easiest format. If you don't have a utility bill in the Business's name, then you can provide the Official Business Registration, Business License, or Tax Certificates.
 
In addition, it would be helpful if we submit an exterior photo of your business and any additional signage you might have near the street with the company name/logo.
 
If you have any questions, let us know.

Thanks in advance,
[ Your name ]
Google Business Profile (GBP) Suspensions

SVGO and modifications that allow styling (size, color, etc.) where used.
SVGs Optimized for Tailwind v4+

SVGOMG.net - online optimizer.

SVGO - optimizer for NodeJS and CLI. (GitHub)

Set your SVG's fill attribute to just "currentColor" always.

Make sure the viewBox attribute is set to something that makes sense. Remember that this will set (infer) the aspect ratio.

For logos, icons, etc., always ONLY set the height and allow the width to be inferred.

For code readability, convert the SVG to a function or component and pass in the catch-all contents of a class attribute. [TODO finish and test the code example below for .cshtml @functions {} as well as similar usage in ThemeObjects (.ascx user controls)]

Definition:

  /// <summary>
  /// AccuStandard pattern for an SVG Component in Razor C# .cshtml
  /// </summary>
  /// <param name="Classes">default: "h-5", one or more space-separated classes</param>
  /// <param name="Fill">default: "currentColor", one (color) class</param>
  /// <param name="Stroke">default: "", one (color) class</param>
  /// <returns>an SVG (HtmlString)</returns>
  public IHtmlString SvgMenuDropdownIcon(
    string Id = "dropdown-chevron",
    string Classes = "h-5",
    string Fill = "currentColor", 
    string Stroke = "",
    string Viewbox = "0 0 20 20"
  )
  {
    return new HtmlString($@"
      <svg id='{Id}' class='{Classes}' fill='{Fill}' stroke='{Stroke}' viewBox='{Viewbox}' aria-hidden='true' data-slot='icon' data-chevron>
        <path fill-rule='evenodd' d='M5.22 8.22a.75.75 0 0 1 1.06 0L10 11.94l3.72-3.72a.75.75 0 1 1 1.06 1.06l-4.25 4.25a.75.75 0 0 1-1.06 0L5.22 9.28a.75.75 0 0 1 0-1.06Z' clip-rule='evenodd' />
      </svg>
      ".Trim()
    );
  }

Usage:


<div class="flex items-center space-x-4">
    <a href="https://facebook.com" class="text-blue-600 hover:text-blue-800">
        @SvgMenuDropdownIcon(Classes: "h-8 transition-colors")
    </a>
    <button class="bg-blue-dark text-white p-2 flex items-center">
        <span>View Menu</span>
        @SvgMenuDropdownIcon(classes: "h-8 text-blue-dark hover:text-blue-light")
    </button>
</div>
